title.narrative: Legal Access, Human Rights and Anti-Corruption

description.narrative: Support for Implementing the Policy Plan for Legal Protection and Human Rights, and Anti-Corruption

title.narrative: 00057091_PRODOC HR Access to Justice and Anti Corruption final version 270209

description.narrative: Support for Implementing the Policy Plan for Legal Protection and Human Rights, and Anti-Corruption
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

The Bureau for Human Rights functioning at a level where it reasonably fulfils its mandate, National Human Rights Action Plan defined and implemented, 2 Workshops held for consultations on the Human Rights Plan, at least 6 education programmes on human rights implemented, at least 4 training seminars conducted for the Justice sector (Police, prosecutors, Attorney General’s Office, penitentiary organs), strategy and recommendations for revision of the Police College Curricula, code of ethics and handbooks, published handbooks for the police, penitentiary system, prosecutors, lawyers and judges. At least 40 representatives of CSOs are capable of communicating basic human rights concepts and commence independent advocacy efforts. At least ten articles in major newspapers discussing issues from a human rights perspective in one year, media practitioners trained to report on human rights isses

comment.narrative: Suriname has no Human Rights plan or strategy. There is limited institutional and human resources capacity of the newly-established Bureau for Human Rights, Limited knowledge and awareness among the civil service and justice sectors regarding international human rights norms and principles. Curricula for the training of police officers do not include comprehensive training on international human rights instruments.

title.narrative: Suriname Coast Protect Area Management MSP

description.narrative: GEF-PIMS 4370 BD MSP: Suriname Coastal Protected Area Management project

title.narrative: 00061290_PIMS 4730 BD Suriname Coastal PA ProDoc final 280711
00061290_signature page MSP Suriname Coastal Protected Area Management
Suriname Coast Protect Area Management MSP

description.narrative: The project goal is to safeguard Suriname’s globally significant coastal biodiversity. The project objective is to promote the conservation of biodiversity through improved management of protected areas along the nation’s western coast.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

METT for coastal PA’s
High (70-100): 3 Medium (50-69): 3 Low (<50): 4 Financial Score (Part 2): 38%
(The highest score possible is 196)
Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks: 49%
Business planning & other tools for cost-effective management: 34%
Tools and systems for revenue generation & mobilization: 32%

comment.narrative:
METT for coastal PA’s
High (70-100): 0 Medium (50-69): 3 Low (<50): 7 Financial Score (Part 2): 13% Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks: 18%
Business planning & other tools for cost-effective management: 13%
Tools and systems for revenue generation & mobilization: 1%

i. All draft updated management plans for coastal zone protected area management prepared. ii. Draft monitoring and evaluation system for coastal zone protected areas prepared. iii. Training program for selected coastal protected areas staff prepared and being implemented. iv. All draft business plans for coastal protected areas prepared. v. Economic valuation of one coastal protected areas completed.

description.narrative: Support to the Parliament of Suriname
Support to the Parliament of Suriname to carry out its core duties
independent political entity
Elections - elections

Legislative Drafting Office established and supported by parliament management, status of amendments traceable any time in legislative process. Regular and verifiable interaction with legal staff of all ministries. Guidelines on oversight are followed by Committees. Visitor Information Center operational and generates statistics on its outreach activities. Amount of budget allocated for HR plan and strategy. Institutional PRODOC for Strengthening the National Assembly of Suriname developed. Department for inter-parliamentary relations created and supported by parliament leadership and UNCT regularly provides briefings and notes to MPs. Parliamentary gender agenda designed and implemented.

comment.narrative: The parliament does not have a Legislative drafting office and MP capacity to review or initiate legislation is limited. There is limited in-depth knowledge among MPs on key economic and social development issues. MPs need improvement in skills on presentation, communication, languages. Parliaments financial oversight on government spending is limited. There is limited knowledge on gender budget impact assessments. Insufficient parliamentary oversight on foreign affairs of Suriname. Parliamentary Gender Agenda not in place, number of women MPs decreased with last election.

title.narrative: sound management of chemicals into development planning

description.narrative: Suriname /UNEP /UNDP partnership for the integration of sound management of chemicals into development planning and processes
Integration of sound management of chemicals into development planning and processes.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

National Chemical Commission is perceived to be well functioning and mandated to support the integration of sound chemical management in national and sector planning. Human capacities strengthening through training and knowledge sharing systems to deal with chemicals management at national and local level. Strategy and action plan including improvement in legislative framework for strengthening chemicals management prepared and implemented.

comment.narrative: National Chemical Commission is to be re-established. Very limited resources and capacity to deal with chemicals management problems at national and local level. Suriname has no legislation that is specifically aimed at addressing chemicals management, except for the Pesticides Act.

title.narrative: Feasibility Bio-fuel Production from Arundo donax

description.narrative: Feasibility Study for commercial Production of Bio-fuels from Arundo donax in mined out areas around Moengo in the Republic of Suriname.

The primary goal of the feasibility study, which is supported by pilot scale activities, is to establish the agronomic and techno-economic viability of Arundo donax plantations within the mined-out areas of the Moengo region.
Energy - power generation
Strengthening national capacities of Suriname for the elaboration of the national REDD+ strategy and the design of its implementation framework.
Suriname leaders understand the potential of REDD+ for the country and engage all national and international partners into building the shared vision.
Environment - policy, planning and administration

General and technical understanding of REDD+ by all relevant stakeholders. Level of support to REDD readiness efforts disaggregated by stakeholders and right holders. Capacity of Suriname to integrate gender dimension and ensure women participation in all readiness efforts.

comment.narrative: The level of understanding is limited to the information provided into the R-PP, which has not been widely shared yet. The level of support is limited so far. The R-PP considers gender dimension, but attention to gender issues is generally limited.

Building capacity specifically of the private sector through training and dialogue to enable effective participation in the REDD+ process Supporting the development of local community radios broadcast, network and coverage Ensuring an integrated follow-up and monitoring of implementation, with a dedicated staff within NIMOS to follow up on activities implementation, report on what is being done, collect feedbacks and report on lessons learnt including through audio or video recording Building human capacity and training specific REDD+ institutions like NIMOS, REDD+ assistants, MGC and the REDD+ Steering Committee members Supporting training initiatives or training requests from individual villages after fine-tuning with traditional authorities (considering the implications of geographical distribution of villages on equal involvement of the entire

The PMU is installed and the monthly and quarterly progress reports are being monitored by the implementing partner as well as the UNDP. Most of the activities under this pillar have been delayed. However there was capacity strengthening activities performed for REDD+ assistants, MGC, private sectors. Filed visits were held to local communities to indicate what support is needed for the effective participation in the REDD+ process.

description.narrative: Strengthening national capacities of Suriname for the elaboration of the national REDD+ strategy and the design of its implementation framework

Collective capacity to produce quality deliverables Level of attention toward poverty reduction, human rights based approach and gender consideration in the REDD+ strategy National degree of understanding and consensus on drivers of deforestation

comment.narrative: There is moderate and recent national capacity and experience in strategic planning (OD) and environmental and social impact assessment (NIMOS), and no experience in the case of REDD+ The R-PP offers a first overview of background situation, but remains incomplete for robust REDD+ strategic planning and impact assessment A draft REDD+ option framework has been formulated during the R-PP, and general ESSP was carried out by UNDP as part of the PRODOC No national experience neither in SESA nor in ESMF There are some experiences related to environmental impact assessments in Suriname but not related to system of information on social and environmental safeguards Some elements of the future REDD+ strategy detailed in the RPP. Coherence between OD2012-2016 and REDD+ is weak Precedent of Guyana, which is probably not directly replicable in Suriname Limited contribution of Suriname into international REDD+ process so far No dialogue and no international commitment on international support for phases 2 and 3 of REDD+ in Suriname
work continued on the SESA reporting and ESFM implementation building political awareness and support for the REDD+ vision
The drivers of deforestation are mapped

description.narrative: A comprehensive implementation framework is designed and related instruments are built progressively
Collective capacity to produce quality deliverables Level of attention toward poverty reduction, human rights based approach and gender consideration in the REDD+ implementation framework and tools

comment.narrative: Apart from a few projects related to forest monitoring and delayed processes to design an environmental law and a climate compatible development strategy, there are scarce capacities in place to design a full implementation framework and related instruments for REDD+ implementation. Some historical data on deforestation and degradation are scattered and incomplete. Limited capacity to design scenarios through spatial modelling No experience and capacity in designing reference level. Existing collaboration with Guyana on related topics. Forests are punctually monitored in a weakly coordinated and harmonized manner. Methods and data quality does not match international standards and lacks continuous run up. Legislative branch has moderate awareness of REDD+, little understanding of potential legal implications, and complex reforms are expected to be required to implement REDD+ in Suriname The institutional and financial arrangements needs for REDD+ implementation are roughly assessed
Start institutional capacity strengthening at SBB for the implementation of REDD+ activities related to NFMS, RV and forest REL / RL
The project implementation has been delayed however the Terms of Reference for the NFMS. National Forest Inventory and Database Manger were finalized and advertised.

description.narrative: Suriname is developing and integrating into its national development planning the implementation of Climate Adaptation Actions related to Climatic risks and possible disasters across sectors and at various levels country-wide.
Knowledge and understanding of climate change effects and of opportunities or ways to cope with negative effects are enhanced.

Frequency and accuracy of climate related information and analysis provided by MSD, WLA and other climate change related institutions. Availability of a nationwide water resource (hydrological) model. Number of climate change adaptation measures developed for the agricultural sector.

comment.narrative: The existing hydrological and meteorological network stations managed by MDS and WLA are presently only a broad network, mostly developed for weather (rain and river flood) forecasting purposes though is far from accommodating the variable of local climate over the whole country. Data analysis from WLA is provided on quarterly basis with 80% coverage of coastal area region. Hydrological models in Suriname are too strategic and poorly detailed to help advice at the local level and subsequently do not permit to develop appropriate sectorial or local adaptation strategies. Datasets on hydrology and meteorology are present, but considerable effort is likely to be needed to collate, compile and digitize this work into a format that is useable for modelling purposes. No data is available for the interior regions. MDS provides data analysis (depending on the type of station) for the coastal regions on a daily and monthly basis and less frequented for the interior regions.No national level adaptation measures or policies are available.

Equipment for improvement of Climate change data for the whole country (coastal area region and interior) are purchased. Initial training needs assessment of staff prepared and agreed upon. One (1) water resource related climate change adaptation measures is ready for implementation.
Climate change data for the whole country (coastal area region and interior) are analyzed and publicized on monthly basis. Furthermore, new baseline (real time) meteorological datasets are collated.

description.narrative: Essential tools and structures for sustainable management, focused on conservation of mangrove ecosystems, are in place.

% of mangrove ecosystems under newly established management / legal instruments that allow sustainable use and or limit any use and targeted and enforceable protection “tools” (e.g.: no take zones). % of “Mangrove” managed by a set of norms and guidelines agreed with and coordinated between key Ministries and Departments for the future management of mangroves.

comment.narrative: Nearly the entire coastline of Suriname falls within the country’s system of protected areas. Only a section near the eastern coast border and the highly urbanized central coastal area surrounding Paramaribo are excluded. Still, effective protection is hampered by the lack of proper management structures, outdated management plans and insufficiently organised and equipped patrolling teams. In spite of the extensive system of protected areas, mangrove trees themselves do not benefit from a legal protection status.
Identification on the legal instruments for essential planning “tools” to ensure their long term sustainable management by end of year one.

25% of the countries mangroves are covered by legal instruments for essential planning “tools” to ensure their long term sustainable management by end of year three. At least 80% of the country’s mangroves are managed through a set of formalized guidelines by end of year two.

description.narrative: Mainstreaming global environment commitments for effective national environmental management.

Strengthen key government structures, as well as mechanisms for the civil society sector, to improve the institutional framework set up to implement the Rio Conventions and to deliver global environmental benefits.
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Degree to which environmental data/information is available and accessible to government and civil society. Existence of an agreed roadmap towards the development of a legislative and institutional framework for environmental management at national level.

comment.narrative: The following information is available disparately but not accessible to end-users in a comprehensive way: national biodiversity information under NBINS; development indicators under DEVINFO; statistical information under ABSinfo; water-related data under SWRIS; land registration and land information system under GLIS; forestry information under NFI, conservation data by NARENA. There is not an agreed roadmap towards the development of a legislative and institutional framework for environmental management at the national level.
Project signed on the 30/10/2015. Project implementation further delayed

Technical Assistance to the Ministry of Regional Development
